abstract: Trapit, a start-up that opens to the public Tuesday, offers a new way to search the Web for topics by using machine learning. It is trying to provide an alternative to Google’s search engine and link sharing on Facebook and Twitter.
snippet: Trapit, a start-up that opens to the public Tuesday, offers a new way to search the Web for topics by using machine learning. It is trying to provide an alternative to Google’s search engine and link sharing on Facebook and Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Though Web search is dominated by Google and supplemented by link-sharing on Facebook and Twitter, a start-up, Trapit, which opens to the public Tuesday, thinks it can offer a smarter, more personalized way to search for topics.

headline.main: A Start-Up Offers a New Way to Search the Web

abstract: Google, which already offers 360-degree street-level views of New York City and other cities, has turned its attention to parks and other locations inaccessible by car with its Trike, a panoramic camera system with nine lenses mounted on an oversize tricycle. Read the full Times article by Lisa W. Foderaro.
snippet: Google, which already offers 360-degree street-level views of New York City and other cities, has turned its attention to parks and other locations inaccessible by car with its Trike, a panoramic camera system with nine lenses mounted on an oversi...
lead_paragraph: Google, which already offers 360-degree street-level views of New York City and other cities, has turned its attention to parks and other locations inaccessible by car with its Trike, a panoramic camera system with nine lenses mounted on an oversize tricycle. Read the full New York Times article by Lisa W. Foderaro.

headline.main: Quietly, Google Gets Its View of the Park

abstract: Google, under pressure from regulators, will offer people the option to keep names and locations of their Wi-Fi routers out of a company database.
snippet: Google, under pressure from regulators, will offer people the option to keep names and locations of their Wi-Fi routers out of a company database.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Google, under pressure from privacy regulators in the Netherlands, said Tuesday that it had agreed to give people around the world the option of keeping the names and locations of their home or business Wi-Fi routers out of a company database.

headline.main: Google Allows Wi-Fi Owners to Opt Out of Database
headline.print_headline: Google Agrees to Allow Owners of Wi-Fi Routers to Opt Out of Database
